content.description: From the right end of the fixed line, this line takes the right line of bolts, angling right and ending at the chains hanging at the highest point of the crag.
content.location: From the upper ledge, this line starts from the right end of the fixed line, taking the right of the two lines. It might be a good idea to have your belayer on the ground for this one.

content.description: Start just left above the right traversing fixed line. Make big moves to awesome jugs up to the start of the crack. Then left foot on a pinky nail sized pebble and high right drop-knee to set up for the crux move to a hidden crimp-jug with your right. This route was originally given 5.11b but feels a little softer.
content.location: This is next route over right from Alley Cat.

content.description: This has some funky, fun climbing up through several overhangs. Two of the roof moves feel like topping out a boulder problem and made me smile. The crux is more technical than the rest of the climb, and it made me try twice, it comes up high at the last bolt. It could use a little more traffic to clean up better, but all the necessary holds were clean and felt solid. Why am I complaining about a little dirt, the friction is great on these newish routes? I think all the Nathans out there should climb this arete.
content.protection: 7 bolts and anchors from which to lower.
content.location: This is the far rightmost route on this wall.

content.description:
London Arete is another great route by Ben! The line take the obvious overhanging arete left of "

Intercontinental

" with an obvious crux bulge. It is bouldery and powerful with super fun sequences. The only detractor is that it seriously leaves you wanting more. Some feel it's stout for the grade, and it won't disappoint. This is very worth doing!
content.location: It is the first route from the West at the Plebian Wall. The start is in a nest of large boulders with a fairly high first bolt. The second bolt is at the big horizontal break before the business starts.

content.description: This stellar line takes the center of the detached pillar forming a small cave on the left side of the cliff. This short but truly beautiful line incorporates a variety of technical moves on bullet hard stone. It is very photogenic and sustained the entire way. This route was originally given 5.10c, but it feels a little softer than that, so tell me if I am wrong.
content.location: This is on the big rock that looks like Africa (left side if you are looking directly at The Plebian Wall).

content.description:
This route is around the corner to the right of the main wall

Start by stepping over an overlap on some long reaches but with good holds that make the move fairly straightforward. Then you are in the real crux of the route which is a shallow dihedral/groove in which delicate footwork, stemming, slopping, and pinching allow you to work up to an upper bulge and another overlap.

This is delicate, intricate, and fun. The style is a great change of pace for the wall!

If this is your route, please update anything here. I just enjoyed it, so I thought I'd share. Thanks for the hard work bolting this area!
From the ground at The Plebian Wall, this takes the second from the right line up whiter stone and finishes on the right side of the apex of the wall.
content.location: From the ground, it's the second from the right line of bolts.

content.description: This is a short climb overcoming the bulge about 10 feet up finishing with 25 feet of easy class 3 slab.
content.location: If you were looking straight at ??, head up and right through the little valley hugging the wall on your left (over about 7 feet of Class 2 rock). This is the last route in the very back near the tree.

content.description:
A bolted boulder problem, this climbs through the overhang from the ground to the bolts at the right end of of the fixed line. Link this after the ledge with

Arco Arena

or

Shotgun Piñata

for a 5.12d or 5.13a line.
content.protection: 2 bolts to the fixed line on the ledge.
content.location: From the ground, climb the bolted boulder problem, and top out on the ledge.

content.description:
Start off the right end of the fixed line, following the left line of bolts. This route gets progressively harder, transitioning from jugs to crimps and culminating in a sharp, powerful, and possibly dynamic crux to get past the anchors before you can clip them.

This is a well-bolted and safe route, although the last two clips are somewhat tough since you're in the crux. I had my belayer belay from the ground and started from the fixed line on the ledge.
content.location: Up the hole to the ledge on the left of Plebian, this line leads left from the right end of the fixed line.

content.description: Sequential and sustained crimping gets you to jugs at the anchors. This is well bolted, but an attentive belay is still necessary due to the boulder behind.
content.location: From the upper ledge, this is the furthest left route.
